poem:
### Saginaw Rallies

In Saginaw, voices rise—  
a chorus of clamor,  
not for policy charts,  
but a balm for the bruise,  
a golden whisper of yesterday.  
There, where truth bends,  
a carnival's embrace warms—  
and hearts, eager,  
clap for promises  
wrapped in vibrant veils,  
flying high.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Democrats on edge in critical Michigan amid fears of waning enthusiasm Donald Trump’s supporters do not pitch up at his rallies expecting to hear policy speeches or even the truth. Mostly they go for the comfort of distractions from hard realities and the allure of false promises to revive the past. But some of the loudest cheers at Trump’s recent rally in Saginaw, Michigan, came in response to a claim the former US president’s supporters". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
